Blumenberg demonstrates this capacity of myths to evolve by devoting the second half of his book to a case study of the myth of Prometheus from its earliest appearance in Hesiod to its twentieth-century versions in Kafka and Gide. It is for this reason that Wendy O’Flaherty describes myths as a “palimpsest on which generation after generation has engraved its own layer of messages.” See Women, Androgynes, and Other Mythical Beasts
